description: From Middle English crochet, from Old French crochet (“small hook”), from croc + -et (diminutive suffix), from Old Norse krókr (“hook”). The musical note was named so because of a small hook on its stem in black notation (in modern notation this hook is on the quaver/eighth note). Doublet of crochet, crocket, and croquet.

entries.meaning: (music) A musical note one beat long in 4/4 time.
(obsolete) A sharp curve or crook; a shape resembling a hook
(surgery, now chiefly historical) A hook-shaped instrument, especially as used in obstetric surgery.
examples: Either Doctor Denman or an old Woman would have waited—but since the horrid death-doing Crotchet has been found out, & its use permitted—Oh! many & many a Life has been flung away.
He ruined himself and all that trusted in him by crotchets that he could never explain to any rational man.

entries.meaning: (military, historical) An indentation in the glacis of the covered way, at a point where a traverse is placed.
(military) The arrangement of a body of troops, either forward or rearward, so as to form a line nearly perpendicular to the general line of battle.

verbs.description: crotchet (third-person singular simple present crotchets, present participle crotcheting, simple past and past participle crotcheted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) to play music in measured time
Archaic form of crochet (knit by looping)
